image.altText: A graphic image of a broken "for lease" sign against a background of grid paper. A line of cartoon people run behind it.

items.synopsis: Across the housing sector, from renters to real estate agents and landlords, there's broad agreement that Australia's rental system needs an overhaul — and fast. The problem is, few agree on what that change should look like.

title.children: 'This has been a long time coming': How the cracks in Australia’s rental market were revealed

image.altText: A photo of NT Opposition Leader Lia Finocchiaro making an announcement. She is wearing a blue top and black blazer.

items.synopsis: In a jurisdiction where 30 per cent of the population identify as Indigenous, Lia Finocchiaro is playing a delicate balancing act by publicly announcing her opposition to the Voice.

title.children: The NT Opposition Leader says her anti-Voice vote is purely personal – but political lines are drawn

image.altText: A woman sitting on a darkened stage looking up and smiling, while holding an owl puppet.

items.synopsis: A chance meeting at the markets led to a cross-cultural collaboration between Larrakia elder June Mills and the Darwin Symphony Orchestra that's captured the imaginations of local children.

title.children: Larrakia elder June Mills tells her traditional story Witladla with a classical twist

image.altText: A NT police officer standing next to a police vehicle, with his back the camera, on a sunny day.

items.synopsis: Code one call-outs – which should be acted on within 10 minutes – are now taking an average of 43 minutes to receive a police response across most of the NT, the coroner has heard.

title.children: 'They feel as if police don't care': DV inquest hears police response times more than doubled in five years

image.altText: President of Spain's soccer federation, Luis Rubiales, right, hugs Spain's Aitana Bonmati.

items.synopsis: Spanish soccer player Jenni Hermoso says that "in no moment" did she consent to a kiss on the lips by soccer federation president Luis Rubiales at the Women's World Cup final.

title.children: Spanish footballer says kiss from federation president was not consensual, World Cup winners refuse to play in protest

image.altText: A window shows a pink sun set over an airplane.

items.synopsis: It's the sneaky travel hack that's been used by savvy consumers for years. Here's what we know about skiplagging.

title.children: What is skiplagging? The travel hack long hated by airlines is now the subject of a big lawsuit

image.altText: Ken Henry #4

items.synopsis: The latest Intergenerational Report paints a picture of an Australian landscape working in a very different way to ones we have seen in the past. There is no room for blank spots, writes Laura Tingle.

title.children: Australia is facing an intergenerational 'tragedy' that demands big picture discussions about the future

image.altText: Malka Leifer leans against a car on a street in Israel talking to two men

items.synopsis: A private investigator explains how an undercover operation in a remote community where "everyone knows everyone" helped nab disgraced principal, Malka Leifer.

title.children: How hidden cameras helped force an abuser from her remote, overseas location to face justice in Australia

image.altText: Paul Smith grocery shopping in the vegetable section of the supermarket

items.synopsis: Supermarket theft is on the rise, costing the industry hundreds of millions of dollars annually. The crime wave is not just hitting Australia — it's proving to be a major global issue as inflation pressures bite and organised gangs seize opportunities.

title.children: Supermarkets roll out high tech to catch shoplifters as cost-of-living pressures bite

image.altText: Two police walking in front of fatal crash scene

items.synopsis: Two boys die in hospital and a crime scene is set up after a car hit a tree in the Sydney suburb of Monterey.

title.children: Boys aged nine and 10 die after car crashes into tree at Monterey in Sydney's south

image.altText: Yevgeny Prigozhin leaves a cemetery. He is bald and stares at the camera from a distance.

items.synopsis: Once a petty criminal who served time in a Russian penal colony for stealing a woman's boots off her feet, Yevgeny Prigozhin cut a ruthless path to power. His end may have been just as violent.

title.children: Prigozhin's appetite for violence and his raw ambition propelled his life. It also destroyed him

image.altText: A woman's leg in a red show with a flat heal kicks in the air over a puddle

items.synopsis: Ballet flat shoes are making a comeback. Are they safer than stilettos? When you look at the research a complicated picture emerges.

title.children: Ballet flats are back. Here’s what the research says about how they affect your feet

image.altText: Colour portrait of rapper Briggs sitting on a chair in front of black background and some red light.

items.synopsis: As I sat looking at the restaurant bill, Briggs' words took me back to a place I still feel like I've never really left: the uni student who couldn't make ends meet, writes Virgina Trioli.

title.children: The fear of being broke never really does go away

image.altText: Aerial drone image of two swimmers swimming along a roped-off area at a beach in blue-green water.

items.synopsis: A wide-ranging swimming ban has hit New Caledonia's tourism industry hard, forcing some job-seekers to return to work in the mines. So what are some long-term solutions for the Pacific island nation beyond shark nets and culls?

title.children: A swimming ban in an island paradise has impacted local tourism. Are shark nets and culling the answer?

image.altText: Rescue workers in helmets and masks wheel a stretcher loaded with gear along pavement under a yellow police tape.

items.synopsis: With low murder rates and strict firearm controls, South Korea has long been considered safe but after a recent series of stabbing rampages some are calling for greater police powers and harsher sentences for violent crimes.

title.children: What's behind South Korea's 'don't ask why' stabbing attacks?

image.altText: A colourful illustration, one half is a woman on a couch reading and the other half is a person in a chair readng

items.synopsis: Our favourite new reads include an ode to the pleasures of a simple life, a Booker Prize-nominated dystopian chiller, and a tantalising glimpse into the life of Vincent Van Gogh's hidden muse.

title.children: The six books our critics couldn't put down this month

image.altText: An aerial photo of a coal power plant surrounded by Australian bush.

items.synopsis: Renewable energy is increasingly the main game in Australia's electricity system, so why are governments stepping in to prop up ageing coal-fired plants?

title.children: 'Mugged by reality': Why taxpayers are on the hook for keeping coal plants online

image.altText: A small group of US Marines crouching or standing in a row in red dirt, holding rifles.

items.synopsis: Northern Territory leader Natasha Fyles is heading abroad at a time when Australia is shifting its defence focus to the north.

title.children: NT chief minister bound for Washington DC to bolster ties with US military

image.altText: Adam Cranston surrounded by sister Lauren, Jason Onley, Dev Menon, Patrick Willmott and in the background a faded ATO sign in

items.synopsis: When they spoke with confidence about the scam they had devised, the people behind one of Australia's biggest tax frauds unwittingly set a challenge for some of the country's best forensic accountants.

title.children: 'Immoral but not illegal': The lies conspirators behind Australia's largest tax fraud told themselves

image.altText: A glass cabinet with art inside is shattered, the shattered glass is on the floor.

items.synopsis: Windows, computer equipment and "beloved cultural treasures" are damaged during a spate of break-ins, described as  "devastating" and "frustrating" by those left to clean up the mess.

title.children: Overnight break-ins a 'punch in the guts' for Alice Springs school, cultural precinct and cafe

image.altText: Tran family in Mekong Restaurant

items.synopsis: The Tran family have worked hard to build their lives in Australia — running and owning an award-winning restaurant — but they say after receiving incorrect migration advice, they could lose it all.

title.children: 'Home is here': Celebrated restaurant owning-family fears for future after 'bad migration advice'

image.altText: Matildas players watch on at pitchside as Australian fans in the stands cheer and hold up signs after a big match.

items.synopsis: The Women's World Cup showed Australia can be a footballing nation, but the people in charge have to figure out how to extend that for more than a couple of months.

title.children: With the Women's World Cup in the rear-view mirror, now the real work begins for Australian football to cash in

image.altText: Ricciardo stands up in crashed F1 car

items.synopsis: AlphaTauri's Ricciardo, in just his third grand prix since earning a drive with the Red Bull-backed outfit, fractured his left hand when he and fellow Australian Oscar Piastri crashed on the same turn.

title.children: Daniel Ricciardo to miss Dutch Grand Prix after fracturing hand in crash

image.altText: Mackenzie Little holds Aus flag and wears medal smiling at camera

items.synopsis: Positioned outside of the top three heading into the final round, Australia's Mackenzie Little lifts herself onto the podium at the World Athletics Championships in Budapest, while two-time defending champion Kelsey-Lee Barber finishes outside of the medals.

title.children: Aussie produces clutch effort on final throw to snare javelin bronze at world titles

image.altText: An 1800s colour illustration of a man inspecting a woman's head, as another man looks on, surrounded by plaster heads

items.synopsis: Phrenology promised human insight based on a skull's shape. It was soon scientifically discredited, but here's how it still flourished in Australia.

title.children: Could you have the 'tendency to murder' based on the shape of your head? These Australians thought so

image.altText: A woman with black hair stands in a restaurant and smiles

items.synopsis: Mental health has long been a focus for restaurant owner Bianca, but more recently the trauma of losing her baby son has meant she's had to put everything she's learnt into practice in her own life.

title.children: Bianca made mental health a priority for her business — and has had to put everything she's learnt into practice in her own life

image.altText: A close up of a grey, fluffy koala in a tree, looking right at the camera.

items.synopsis: Dog owners living in parts of the Gold Coast must now follow strict rules or face fines under tough laws designed to keep koalas safe. But wildlife rescuers fear the plan could backfire.

title.children: New fences, dogs inside at night, backyard escape routes required under council's new koala protection laws

image.altText: A honey bee sticking its head into honeycomb.

items.synopsis: New research from UNSW Canberra reveals the amazing natural design of a honey bee's stinger, and the potential advancements it could inspire in the next generation of micro medical tools.

title.children: How this little insect's stinger is inspiring the next generation of micro medical devices

image.altText: A 30-something Pakistani Australian woman with long dark hair wears a purple shirt and is seated on a loungeroom floor, painting

items.synopsis: Rubaba's mother Zakia is the driving force behind her art career in countless ways. Now Rubaba has won the Australian Muslim Artists Art Prize.

title.children: Rubaba's mother sacrificed everything so her daughter could become an artist — now she's a prize winner

image.altText: the outside of the building with a glass facade

items.synopsis: Crown Resorts cited "macro-economic challenges" for its decision this week to close one of its two gaming floors and shed 95 staff, just a year after it opened in Sydney's tallest skyscraper.

title.children: Crown Sydney left 'high and dry' after betting on lure of VIP gamblers, expert says

image.altText: Indicted

items.synopsis: Former US president Donald Trump again stands accused of illegally trying to overturn the 2020 election results to stay in power. These are his codefendants.

title.children: Eighteen people have been indicted alongside Donald Trump in Georgia. This is who they are and how they are involved

image.altText: Satellite image of a plane wreckage in a rural-looking area with trees, fields and a few buildings nearby

items.synopsis: Despite Russian President Vladimir Putin sending the Wagner mercenary boss' family his condolences, the Kremlin says it needs to wait for test results.

title.children: Russia says flight recorders and 10 bodies recovered from wreckage of Prigozhin plane
